cons: It was a pros to receive a stipend for TA work but these days the pay is nothing compared to other schools! you can barely make it! they have not increased the salary for graduate students since 2014!!! The whole Pharmaceutical and chemical sciences program is a disaster. Only a few labs are active and have grants. there is no high-impact research here! Small labs with few students, no collaborations no fun events for the students and the administration is awful. They are basically killing the program and everything is getting worse here. Just think about other schools.

job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Stockton, CA
pros:
There are amazing staff members that truly love and care for the well-being of the students and University. 

Beautiful campus
cons: Management is very traditional and narrow-minded. Unfortunately, there are few opportunities to grow in within departments. Senior management seems to prefer to bring in external candidates for senior positions instead of allowing those who have a good understanding of the department and university culture to grow. The unfortunate part is that the employees that are not given the opportunity to be promoted end up teaching the new employees how everything works.

pros: The people here are very kind. Lots of flexibility. You get the last week of December off.
cons: Lots of disconnect and miscommunication between departments. Pay is terrible and there is no opportunity for promotions. Benefits are not great.

pros: * Great Coworkers and Supervisors * Great People

job_title: Instructor, College Or University in Stockton, CA
pros: Beautiful campus; some students are worth the effort, generally a friendly place, compensation has improved (prior to COVID), freedom in the classroom
cons: Quality of the students has gone down over the past 15 years. There is a lack of leadership. Leadership hasn't a clue what goes on in the departments and classrooms, thus provides little meaningful support. There is a lack of vision with leadership. They cater more to donors. Faculty need more input and power to help govern. Management continues to squeeze departmental/faculty budgets and tenure lines, yet continue to hire administrators and managers. Same old story as other dysfunctional, top heavy institutions. Little hope of change, since it is administrators who must affect change. Actions, not words are what matter.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Stockton, CA

cons: Working with professors to help students is a great experience, but sometimes you might be assigned to a random course that you are not too familiar with.

review_title: After School Program through the Jacoby Center
pros: This was a very good first job especially for aspiring teachers. You get thrown into creating lesson plans and leading  a class of students in various engaging activities (I got hired after the school year started and unfortunately missed out on the training offered before the school year started). The program has certain guidelines to follow but the rest of your lesson plan can be quite flexible. As long as the students are learning and engaged in the activity planned out for them, it's a good indicator that you're doing well. Management has a good open-door policy if you need assistance.
cons: Unless you wish to pursue a career in teaching/education/working with children, you may struggle as you're doing your best to lead a class and/or feel that you're wasting your time. You will definitely feel discouraged. Don't be. Do your best to stick it out for the school year. There will be a lot of personal growth.

pros:
-Many staff members are friendly
-Many students very respectful and polite
-Benefits package is good
-Respected in the community
-Can get a big discount if you or your kids take classes there
cons:
Multiple problems with management:
-Micromanaging
-Spending too much time on some projects that are not that important  
-Lack of respect 
-Does not listen to its workers
-Sometimes too much work
-Workers seem to get sick a lot from working too hard or stress
-Can't really talk freely at work because you feel that you will get in trouble if you do
Problems with Workers:
-Lack of communication
-Some workers spend a lot of time complaining and not doing anything about the problems
-Some workers talk badly about each other
-Lacking in motivation sometimes

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Stockton, CA
pros: Very hands on experience in the classroom, experience working in teams.  Freedom to express creativity and enthusiasm in the classroom.
cons: Size of your TA/lab team varies on the class you're assigned to teach, and you aren't offered much choice when it comes to which class you will teach.  Your experience (i.e. how much work you must do behind the scenes) depends very much on which class you teach.    The time commitment is sometimes quite significant when taking graduate coursework at the same time.

review_title: Masters of Biological Sciences student at the University of the Pacific
pros: Being a teaching assistant for the Biology Department was great experience. The pay for the amount of worked required for this position was more than generous. All of the professors are very helpful, nice and understand. Some of them will be dead honest with you so it is a good reality check. Monthly TGIFs allow the faulty, teaching assistants and other researchers a little time to relax and have fun. Free food is always a plus of course.
cons: It is quite difficult to juggle between research, teaching and another job so most masters students end up living off of the stipend.

pros: Pay not the very best for the industry but the atmosphere is great and the people are even better. Its still a job at the end of the day but working at Pacific isn't a hassle and there is lots of freedom in how you go about your day.
cons: Pay could be better (where is that not true) and of course you have to be in Stockton. The city isn't as bad as people say but it isn't the greatest by any means.

review_title: Pacific is an OK place to work.
pros: I agree with the other reviews, so no sense in reinventing the wheel.  Pacific is generally a good place to work.  Most mid and high level managment-types are respectful and friendly, but there are some that take their positions a little too seriously.  But, you will find that is the case at most companies.
cons: Human Resources Department does not enforce its own policies.  Each hiring department can do what they want without any oversight.  This can cast a negative light on prospective employees or current employees that want to transfer or move up.

pros: The ability to focus on your projects without too many extraneous distractions. Very creative group of people. I hope this campus is eventually able to shine at the same level as other WCC campuses. They have the vision to do so.
cons:
-Long days. Some game days you will have to start at 9am, and go until 10pm. Setting up and tearing down equipment became a routine that took too long, and there weren't enough students to pay to help. 
-Living in Stockton.

review_title: Conditionally good as far as universities go.
pros: Attractive campus; good retirement with TIAA-CREF if you stick within education long enough (many years).
cons: Lack of focus on the bottom-line, relatively common to higher-education; lack of opportunities for growth if you are in a specialized discipline; low pay among academics who work there. Three campus locations can make managing common projects affecting all three locations challenging, as there is no centralized authority except through the school's Dean. So if you need cooperation from someone in a position whose work impacts yours but they work on another campus, you have no leverage except your tongue and good looks.

review_title: Great Place to Work as a Student
job_title: Student Engagement Representative in Stockton, CA
pros: The work-student-life balance is great and they'll really work with your schedule if you need to take more or fewer hours any given week.  Fantastic support from the Alumni Relations office, shoutout to Amy, they really give you set you up to do as much work as you'd life.  Up to 20 hours though.
cons: Wasn't really too much to complain about, the monthly meetings could be kind of boring, but it helps prepare you for a corporate job where they're throwing boring meetings at you all the time.

review_title: Sad place to work for faculty (both permanent and temporary)
job_title: Adjunct Faculty Member in Stockton, CA
pros:
Beautiful campus
Wonderful students who are eager to learn
Decent food
cons:
Faculty is payed very poorly.
Administration does not respect faculty.  Every time a full-time professor retires his/her position is eliminated and couple adjuncts are hired to replace him/her. 
Faculty wrote a letter of disapproval to regents and many UOP students went on strike last year. Regents had no choice but remove the president Pamela Eibeck.. Her last day was June 30th.  
The recent development is to put 40-50 students in each class when the university traditionally advertised small classes. Many classrooms only have capacity for 25 students, which means students have to sit on floor while they are paying $45000 per year in tuition.

pros: Attractive campus and generally nice student population. Little oversight for instructors, so one, within limits, has great academic freedom.
cons: Incompetent department chairs (in my department), unethical practices within departments, poor decisions of upper management.

job_title: Financial Aid Receptionist in Stockton, CA
pros: Worked there a few years ago so from what I hear things are different now. But it was a pretty easy-going job, often being able do homework or surf the internet when things were slow. Boss was pretty understanding of our position as a student and was flexible. Even planned for schedules to change during finals week.
cons: Having to screen angry parents calling about their kid's financial aid.

review_title: Excellent Place to Work and Learn
pros:
-Salary and benefits are very strong. HR does continuing studies to ensure all staff and especially faculty members have salaries that are competitive. Tuition Remission program for dependents is a huge draw (has some rules) and the 403b plan cannot be beat (10% match). Strong health, dental, and other medical plans. Normal vacation and sick time accruals.
-Cost of living is much lower in California's Central Valley; however, if you want a dose of the Big City, SF, Sacramento, and Oakland are only an hour or two away.
-Fairly decent leadership; although, the University is going through some challenging times trying to figure out and properly implement the 2020 plan.
-Faculty are top notch! Since this is not a research University, faculty concentrate on teaching and helping students. It is what sets Pacific apart from others.
-The campus is beautiful and plenty to do.
-Surprisingly wide away of financial aid options for students. 
-On campus food is very good! I eat at the DeRosa Center daily. Lots of options.
-Students are mostly fantastic. Incredibly smart and active.
cons:
-The City of Stockton has some nice features but the city is also in bankruptcy. I feel safe in the safe places. There are some places in Stockton that I will simply not venture through. Thankfully, the area around the University is safe. The University also has its own police force, and since they are also Stockton PD Reserve Officers, they have arrest authority on and off campus.
-$50K per year overall price tag is pretty steep for anyone. However, plenty of grants and scholarships available. Good place for veterans too as the school participates in VA educational benefit programs.
-Parking can be a bit tough on occasion and employees and students must purchase a parking pass.
-Dorm rooms are very small and getting pretty old. The University needs to build or reconfigure most of their dorms. Oh, excuse me, residence halls...

pros:
- Beautiful campus with conservatory of music and  active cultural style
- Nice educational environment
cons:
-  Uneducated  vulgar style in a workplace  in a senior worker can spoil positive 
    progress and does not belong in edu.   
-   Review management  from bottom up    
 -  Offer better support thru HR

review_title: Incredible, working for Services for Students with Disabilities is inspiring, motivational and most of all fun!
job_title: Disability Services Provider in Stockton, CA
pros: I feel respected within my department and like I am truly making a difference in the lives of students and faculty on campus.
cons: Not recognized enough for what our department does by the university. We are understaffed and could really use help especially considering the rapid increase in students requiring special needs.

review_title: Straightforward and an excellent supporting staff.
pros: Plenty of resources and help outside the actual job. For example, access to personal services like health and dental care. Not to mention it was located on a University Campus with plenty of opportunity to attend lectures with guest speakers and other events occurring on campus.
cons: The surrounding area is somewhat dangerous. Despite the police presence on campus, a number of criminal incidents still occur (bike theft being the most common, cars being broken into being the second most common).

pros: The university of the pacific is the best dental school. The reason for this is because the staff, students,'and faculty practice humanism and give their best effort within the Dugoni family.
cons: The environment is very efficient, in doing so it can be difficult to find the right faculty when you need them. The faculty have an open door policy, which helps combat this.

review_title: Great university, not a great city.
pros: One of the nicest college campuses I have ever seen...very scenic with lots of trees.  People are great on campus and really buy into the school!
cons: The surrounding area of Stockton is a dreadful place to live, you have to be really careful in knowing where you want to live because you are never too far from a nasty area of town. It is a very patchy city.

review_title: Reap the Rewards of your Efforts; Face University Bureaucracy
pros:
Entire experience can be very rewarding and insightful if you put the time and energy into your office's and Senate-wide initiatives. 

Lots of change expected to come in the coming year, meaning lots of opportunities to help enhance various aspects of the University.
cons: Doesn't have as much power as University leadership lets on. Due to distrust and apathy in University leadership/administration activities, makes job to engage other students that much harder.

review_title: Fantastic work environment indoors and outdoors - it's like working on an Ivy League campus here on West Coast.
job_title: Director MBA Career Services in Stockton, CA
pros: Great opportunities to pursue advanced education as a staff member at a very affordable price.  As a staff member I have enjoyed opportunities to participate on search committees and in leadership roles on a Staff Advisory Council that has a good dialogue with University Administration.
cons: Sometimes staff get lost in the shuffle of students and faculty.

pros: Pacific is rewarding because of the commitment to our students, whether you are faculty and staff. Everyone knows the students are the priority, and that makes it a rewarding place to work.
cons: The goals seem to change year to year and we have too many priorities. We lack administrative or strategic focus. Resources are thin, which makes it hard to compete with other universities.

review_title: My experience has been laid-back, fun, and overall awesome.
job_title: Summer Conference Supervisor in Stockton, CA
pros: The pay is fair, even excessive for some positions. Management is friendly and approachable. Schedules are very flexible as well, especially if it conflicts with your academics. Summer housing staff is provided with free housing for the summer.
cons: Poor communication between management and employees.

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Stockton, CA
pros: They pay for your schooling and a living stipend.  If you choose student insurance, they pay that too.
cons:
Classes aren't always available but are still required within a certain time frame to graduate and/or remain a student.
Living stipend doesn't get you into the greatest part of Stockton alone (need to room with others and share cost or go to some of the less friendly parts of town)

job_title: Student Office Assistant in Stockton, CA
pros: There's a great staff and support system in this office. I've enjoyed my past year here working as an assistant.
cons: At times you will be filing paperwork weeks at a time. Especially the beginning and end of each school year. Other than that it's very manageable.

review_title: Dangerous undertows in a deceptive river of serenity.
pros: Good benefits, tuition remission and exchange, beautiful campus, summer hours coincide with student's summer break, up to a two week winter holiday break paid
cons: Lack of communication between departments and schools, senior management in some departments seem more like mafia bosses, a lot of politics, a lot of employees fearing for their jobs, almost no opportunity for promotion.

review_title: Nice people...management can't see the forest for the trees.
job_title: Administrative Assistant II in Stockton, CA
pros: Great people work here, smart, innovative, respectful and very helpful.
cons: Most administrative positions do not pay enough. While the benefits are good, they are expensive. Positions that required advanced degrees did not pay well either.

pros: A comfortable job with a good benefits package and competitive pay for the work.

cons: I wish I can give less then one star in-terms of research enviorment and research initiative taken by the faculty member. No work ethics and no help for upper management to improve research enviorment.

pros: A collegial environment, faculty and support work well together in general. Benefits are above average.
cons: President and Provost are ineffective. Athletic school lawsuits cause the rest of the University to suffer through paycuts.

pros: Flexible work schedule, opportunities for growth, and employee recognition.
cons: Middle management is spotty with the revolving student-led management. Social issues are not resolved in an organized manner.

review_title: TA at a Networking Lab where I had to answer questions/troubleshoot lab procedures and grade lab worksheets.
